items.message:
River levels remain high today on the River Mole.

Flooding of low lying land, footpaths and roads close to the River Mole and Burstow Stream remains possible throughout today 19 December 2025.

River levels on the River Mole at Horley are high, but falling steadily and are expected to fall throughout today. River levels on the Burstow Stream at Peeks Brook Lane have fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. Further downstream at Bonehurst Road levels remain high but steady and are expected to continue falling throughout today.

After the heavy rainfall cleared yesterday evening, Thursday 18 December 2025, weather conditions are forecast to improve over the next few days and we expect the risk of flooding to reduce gradually over this period.
 
We are closely monitoring the situation and monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and take care to avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 9:00AM tomorrow, 20 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: River levels remain high on the Rivers Yeo and Parrett following yesterday's rainfall (18/12). Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Yeo, Huish Episcopi Main Drain, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. Huish Episcopi drain levels are rising. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if the drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station exceeds 7.3m; the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m; Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and Muchelney to Drayton above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels. River Parrett levels are being managed using the Parrett relief channel. We are operating our pumping stations when river levels allow. Avoid driving, cycling or walking through flood water. Refer to Somerset Council’s website for any local road closures. This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 20 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

High river levels may cause flooding today 19 December 2025. River levels remain high but are falling in the upper catchment. Levels at Bradford-on-Avon continue to rise but appear to be slowing and are expected to peak in the evening of 19 December 2025.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Semington Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. Generally drier conditions are forecast in the coming days but with some rain on Saturday and Sunday. We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue updates as necessary. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:30 AM on 20 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Stour from Hammoon to Sturminster Marshall
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

The River Blackwater and Cadnam River are high but slowly falling. Flooding will continue on 19/12/2025, as a lot of rain (42mm) fell on Thursday 19/12/2025. Flooding will continue to affect land, fields, and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower throughout today (19/12/2025). Water levels will also be high around the mill building at East Wellow. Only a small amount of rain is forecast over the next 5 days. River levels are expected to return to normal over the next 24 hours. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. Avoid low lying roads near rivers‚ which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 11:00 on 20/12/2025.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Following yesterday's rainfall river levels remain high and flooding is continuing overnight on 19 December on low lying land and roads along the Rivers Eden, Eden Brook and Kent Ditch from Blindley Heath to Penshurst including Edenbridge and Hever. Lingfield and Edenbridge could still be impacted overnight. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 
This message will be updated by 11:00am on 20 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River is still rising in Alfriston. Minor flooding could continue to affect fields near North Street and River Lane, Alfriston. In Hellingly, river levels remain high, but are now slowly falling. Minor flooding could continue to affect fields, gardens, and Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next five days. River levels will continue to slowly fall in Hellingly, and begin to fall in Alfriston by 15:00 19/12/2025. River levels should return nearer to normal by Saturday morning in Hellingly and Saturday evening in Alfriston. We are closely monitoring the situation. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Avoid roads that flood (Mill Lane Church Rd Hellingly, North Street Alfriston). This message will be updated by 14:00 20/12/2025.

The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

The Western Rother is still high and rising at Fittleworth. Water will be close to Fittleworth Mill from 11:00 on 19/12/2025. River levels in Fittleworth are unlikely to begin to fall before 20:00 on 19/12/2025. At Lodsbridge near Selham river levels remain very high and are expected to be affecting property, but river levels should shortly begin to slowly fall. In Iping and Midhurst river levels are high, and will be causing minor flood impacts to Iping Lane, Stedham Lane, gardens near Iping Bridge, and North Mill, but river levels have already fallen a little from their peak. In Liss and Sheet, river levels have already fallen significantly. Only isolated showers are forecast Friday to Monday. River levels between Liss and Midhurst should return nearer to normal by Saturday. Near Fittleworth, river levels will remain higher than normal through the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have, including in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. Avoid roads that flood (Iping). This message will be updated by 12:00 20/12/2025.

River levels continue to rise in response to rainfall yesterday and may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible for: Lower Rivers Tone and Parrett including West Moor, Hay Moor, Curry Moor, Stan Moor, Salt Moor and North Moor. The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station remains high. Water is entering Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway as this level currently exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 6.3m. Cutts Road floods when the drain level at Currymoor pumping station is above 5.75m, and New Road when the level is above 6.18m. Please refer to the latest gauge levels on Check for Flooding and Somerset Council’s website for information on road closures in the area. Further rain is expected this weekend. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Pumping will commence at Currymoor when river levels allow. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 20 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: High and rising groundwater levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible in the West Dorset area. Groundwater levels are rising in response to recent heavy rainfall. Levels may continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Further rainfall is expected over the next few days which may see levels continue to rise. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation . Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 23 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

River levels are receding following recent rain, however levels in the Loe Valley remain high.  We have staff operating culverts to reduce water levels in Loe Pool.

Further heavy rain is forecast on Saturday afternoon. 

We are closely monitoring the situation.     

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.   

This message will be updated by 11AM on 20th December.

Water levels in the Lymington River at Brockenhurst are high but slowly falling. Flooding will continue on 19/12/2025, as a lot of rain (47mm) fell on Thursday 19/12/2025. Flooding will continue to affect land and roads, including Burley Road, Brockenhurst throughout today 19/12/2025. The river will be bank full as it flows through Martin’s Road and Balmer Lawn Road and may cause garden flooding at Balmer Lawn Road. In Lymington itself, the river will rise over the next 3 hours, but we do not expect impacts to property. Only a small amount of rain is forecast over the next 5 days. River levels should return to normal during the next 24 hours. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers‚ sewage and chemicals. Avoid driving through watersplash areas in Brockenhurst. This message will be updated by 11:00 on 20/12/2025.

The River Arun remains high. Isolated property flooding is expected between Broadbridge Heath and Pallingham Quay, including at Wanford. items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cerne Valley
items.message:
High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 
Flooding is expected from the 19th December onwards. 
Groundwater levels in West Dorset remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Charminster and nearby areas. The groundwater level at the Dickley Down borehole has risen to 170m, and is expected to rise over the next few days. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Flooding of roads is expected, and may have become damaged by floodwater.

Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts . 
This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 24 December 2025 or as the situation changes.
